name: signalbot
description: Micro framework to create your own signal bots.
readme_summary: Signalbot is a Python micro-framework designed to simplify the creation of custom Signal bots. It allows developers to easily define commands and integrate them with the signal-cli-rest-api to send and receive messages programmatically.
key_features: Python package for creating Signal bots
Minimal example provided for quick setup
primary_use_case: Developing custom automated messaging bots for the Signal platform.
cover_image_prompt: A friendly robot assistant, resembling a messenger pigeon, is perched on a digital branch. It's holding a glowing scroll with a Signal logo, about to deliver it. Below, a stylized representation of a Signal chat interface shows incoming messages being automatically processed and outgoing messages being sent. Subtle data streams flow between the robot and the chat interface, indicating communication. The background is a clean, modern digital landscape. The overall style is a 3D isometric illustration with soft, inviting lighting and a color palette of blues, greens, and whites, emphasizing efficiency and helpful automation. The repository name 'Signalbot' is subtly integrated into the digital landscape.

name: tlosint-vm
readme_summary: The tlosint-vm repository provides a pre-built Kali Linux virtual machine distribution tailored for OSINT (Open Source Intelligence) tasks, based on the Kali VM build scripts. It also offers a standalone script to customize Kali or Debian-based systems with a curated set of OSINT tools and Firefox hardening.
key_features: Pre-built Kali Linux OSINT VM image (OVA format for VirtualBox and VMware)
Standalone script (tlosint-tools.sh) for on-demand OSINT tool installation on Kali/Debian
Includes curated OSINT tools like Shodan CLI, Sherlock, PhoneInfoga, SpiderFoot, etc.
Applies Firefox hardening for enhanced privacy and security
Provides default login credentials for the pre-built VM
primary_use_case: To provide a ready-to-use virtual machine environment pre-loaded with essential OSINT tools and configurations, or to allow users to easily install and update these tools on their existing Kali/Debian systems.
cover_image_prompt: A digital cartographer in a dimly lit, high-tech study, meticulously assembling a complex map from scattered digital fragments and glowing data streams. The cartographer uses a magnifying glass that reveals intricate network connections and hidden information within the fragments. The map itself is a vibrant, evolving entity, showing interconnected points of interest and pathways. Subtle UI elements displaying code snippets and data visualizations are integrated into the desk and surrounding screens. The overall mood is one of discovery and deep investigation. The style should be a 3D isometric illustration with a dark, atmospheric color palette and glowing accents, emphasizing the 'piecing together' of information.

name: keeweb
description: Free cross-platform password manager compatible with KeePass
readme_summary: KeeWeb is a cross-platform password manager that allows users to manage their credentials in `kdbx` files, compatible with KeePass. It can be used as a browser extension or a desktop application, and supports integration with cloud storage services.
key_features: Cloud storage integration (Dropbox, Google Drive, OneDrive)
primary_use_case: Securely managing and accessing passwords across different platforms and devices, with compatibility for existing KeePass databases.
cover_image_prompt: A wise, old librarian meticulously organizing a vast, glowing library of keys, each key representing a password. The librarian is placing a newly acquired, intricate key into a secure, transparent vault labeled 'KeeWeb'. Around the vault, smaller, stylized icons of cloud services (Dropbox, Google Drive, OneDrive) are visible, with data streams flowing from them towards the vault. In the background, subtle outlines of different operating systems (desktop, browser window) are depicted. The overall mood is secure and organized, with a clean, digital painting style and a color palette of deep blues and glowing golds.

name: tracee
description: Linux Runtime Security and Forensics using eBPF
readme_summary: Tracee is an open-source eBPF-based tool for Linux runtime security and observability. It monitors system and application behavior, exposing activities as events, including sophisticated security detections of suspicious patterns.
key_features: Event generation (system activity and security patterns)
primary_use_case: Monitoring and securing Linux systems and applications at runtime by detecting and reporting on system and security events.
cover_image_prompt: A vigilant digital guardian, represented by a stylized, glowing silhouette of a human figure, stands at the entrance of a bustling digital city. The guardian holds a magnifying glass that reveals the inner workings of data packets flowing into the city, highlighting suspicious activities with a red glow while allowing safe data to pass with a green aura. Subtle UI elements displaying event logs and security alerts are integrated into the city's architecture. The scene is rendered in a clean, 3D isometric illustration style with a futuristic, slightly dark aesthetic, emphasizing clarity and security. The repository name 'Tracee' is subtly etched on the guardian's shield.

name: gitlogue
description: A cinematic Git commit replay tool for the terminal, turning your Git history into a living, animated story.
readme_summary: gitlogue is a terminal-based tool that transforms your Git commit history into a cinematic, animated replay. It visualizes code changes with realistic typing animations, syntax highlighting, and file tree transitions, making the evolution of code an engaging visual experience.
primary_use_case: Visualizing and replaying Git commit history in a cinematic and animated way within the terminal.
cover_image_prompt: A vintage film projector is set up in a dimly lit, cozy study. Instead of a movie screen, the projector beams a dynamic, animated visualization of code unfolding, complete with syntax highlighting and file tree transitions, directly onto a wall. The projected code appears as if being typed in real-time, with subtle digital particles flowing from the projector. The repository name 'gitlogue' is subtly etched onto the side of the projector. The overall mood is one of discovery and storytelling, with a warm, inviting glow emanating from the projected code. The style is a 3D isometric illustration with a focus on atmospheric lighting and clear visual storytelling.
